content_old: 3 asking for themselves as a favour against him, that he would send for him unto Jerusalem,—making an ambush to kill him on the way.

content: 4 Festus therefore､ answered, that Paul should be kept in Cæsarea､ and that he himself was about shortly to be going out thither.
content_old: 4 Festus therefore､ answered, that Paul should be kept in Cæsarea､ and that he himself was about shortly to be going out thither.

content: 5 They､ therefore､ among you (saith he) who are in power let them go down with me; and if there is in the man anything amiss let them accuse him.
content_old: 5 They､ therefore､ among you (saith he) who are in power let them go down with me; and if there is in the man anything amiss let them accuse him.

content: 6 And spending among them､ not more than eight or ten days he went down unto Cæsarea; and on the morrow taking his place upon the judgment-seat ordered Paul to be brought.
content_old: 6 And spending among them､ not more than eight or ten days he went down unto Cæsarea; and on the morrow taking his place upon the judgment-seat ordered Paul to be brought.

content: 7 And when he presented himself the Jews who from Jerusalem had come down､ stood round about him, many and grievous charges bringing against him, which they were not able to prove,—
content_old: 7 And when he presented himself the Jews who from Jerusalem had come down､ stood round about him, many and grievous charges bringing against him, which they were not able to prove,—

content: 8 Paul saying in defence— Neither against the law of the Jews､ nor against the temple, nor against Cæsar have I in anything sinned.
content_old: 8 Paul saying in defence— Neither against the law of the Jews､ nor against the temple, nor against Cæsar have I in anything sinned.

content: 9 But Festus wishing with the Jews to gain favour answered Paul, and said— Art thou willing unto Jerusalem to go up, and there concerning these things be judged before me?
content_old: 9 But Festus wishing with the Jews to gain favour answered Paul, and said— Art thou willing unto Jerusalem to go up, and there concerning these things be judged before me?

content: 10 But Paul said— Standing before the judgment-seat of Cæsar am I, where I ought to be judged. Unto the Jews have I done no wrong, as even thou right well art discovering.
content_old: 10 But Paul said— Standing before the judgment-seat of Cæsar am I, where I ought to be judged. Unto the Jews have I done no wrong, as even thou right well art discovering.

content: 11 If then､ on the one hand､ I am doing wrong, and anything worthy of death have committed I excuse not myself from dying; but､ on the other hand､ if there is nothing in the things whereof these are accusing me no man hath power to give me unto them as a favour:— Unto Cæsar I appeal!
content_old: 11 If then､ on the one hand､ I am doing wrong, and anything worthy of death have committed I excuse not myself from dying; but､ on the other hand､ if there is nothing in the things whereof these are accusing me no man hath power to give me unto them as a favour:— Unto Cæsar I appeal!

content: 12 Then Festus having conversed with the council answered— Unto Cæsar hast thou appealed? Unto Cæsar shalt thou go.
content_old: 12 Then Festus having conversed with the council answered— Unto Cæsar hast thou appealed? Unto Cæsar shalt thou go.

content: 13 And some days having gone by Agrippa the king and Bernicè came down to Cæsarea､ to salute Festus.
content_old: 13 And some days having gone by Agrippa the king and Bernicè came down to Cæsarea､ to salute Festus.

content: 14 And as they were spending more days there Festus repeated unto the king､ the things relating to Paul, saying— A certain man hath been left behind by Felix､ as a prisoner;
content_old: 14 And as they were spending more days there Festus repeated unto the king､ the things relating to Paul, saying— A certain man hath been left behind by Felix､ as a prisoner;

content: 15 concerning whom when I happened to be in Jerusalem the High-priests and the Elders of the Jews laid information, claiming against him a condemnation:
content_old: 15 concerning whom when I happened to be in Jerusalem the High-priests and the Elders of the Jews laid information, claiming against him a condemnation:

content: 16 unto whom I made answer—That it is not a custom with Romans､ to grant as a favour any man､ before the accused face to face should have his accusers, and opportunity of defence should receive､ concerning the charge.
content_old: 16 unto whom I made answer—That it is not a custom with Romans､ to grant as a favour any man､ before the accused face to face should have his accusers, and opportunity of defence should receive､ concerning the charge.

content: 17 When､ therefore､ they had come together here no delay whatever making, on the next day taking my place upon the judgment-seat I ordered the man to be brought:
content_old: 17 When､ therefore､ they had come together here no delay whatever making, on the next day taking my place upon the judgment-seat I ordered the man to be brought:

content: 18 Concerning whom､ taking their stand､ his accusers no accusation at all were bringing､ of the evil things which I had been suspecting;
content_old: 18 Concerning whom､ taking their stand､ his accusers no accusation at all were bringing､ of the evil things which I had been suspecting;

content: 19 but certain questions concerning their own demon-worship had they､ against him, and concerning one Jesus､ who had died, whom Paul was affirming to be alive.
content_old: 19 but certain questions concerning their own demon-worship had they､ against him, and concerning one Jesus､ who had died, whom Paul was affirming to be alive.

content: 20 And I being at a loss as to the inquiry into these things was asking—Whether he might be minded to go unto Jerusalem, and there be judged concerning these things.
content_old: 20 And I being at a loss as to the inquiry into these things was asking—Whether he might be minded to go unto Jerusalem, and there be judged concerning these things.

content: 21 But Paul having appealed to be kept for the decision of the Emperor I ordered him to be kept､ until I could send him up unto Cæsar.
content_old: 21 But Paul having appealed to be kept for the decision of the Emperor I ordered him to be kept､ until I could send him up unto Cæsar.

content: 22 And Agrippa said unto Festus— I could wish myself also to hear the man. To-morrow (saith he) thou shalt hear him.
content_old: 22 And Agrippa said unto Festus— I could wish myself also to hear the man. To-morrow (saith he) thou shalt hear him.

content: 23 On the morrow､ therefore when Agrippa had come､ and Bernicè､ with great display, and they had entered into the audience-chamber, with the captains of thousands and men of distinction of the city,—and Festus had given orders Paul was brought.
content_old: 23 On the morrow､ therefore when Agrippa had come､ and Bernicè､ with great display, and they had entered into the audience-chamber, with the captains of thousands and men of distinction of the city,—and Festus had given orders Paul was brought.

content: 24 And Festus saith— King Agrippa! and all ye men here present with us : Ye observe this person, concerning whom one and all the throng of the Jews have interceded with me, both in Jerusalem and here, crying aloud that he ought not to be living any longer.
content_old: 24 And Festus saith— King Agrippa! and all ye men here present with us : Ye observe this person, concerning whom one and all the throng of the Jews have interceded with me, both in Jerusalem and here, crying aloud that he ought not to be living any longer.

content: 25 But I gathered､ that nothing worthy of death had he committed; and this man himself having appealed unto the Emperor I decided to send him:—
content_old: 25 But I gathered､ that nothing worthy of death had he committed; and this man himself having appealed unto the Emperor I decided to send him:—

content: 26 Concerning whom anything certain to write unto my lord I have not; wherefore､ I have brought him forth before you,—and especially before thee, King Agrippa! in order that after examination had I might have something I could write;
content_old: 26 Concerning whom anything certain to write unto my lord I have not; wherefore､ I have brought him forth before you,—and especially before thee, King Agrippa! in order that after examination had I might have something I could write;

content: 1 And Agrippa unto Paul said—It is permitted thee on thine own behalf to be speaking. Then Paul stretching forth his hand went on to make his defence.
content_old: 1 And Agrippa unto Paul said—It is permitted thee on thine own behalf to be speaking. Then Paul stretching forth his hand went on to make his defence.

content: 2 Concerning all things of which I am accused by Jews, King Agrippa I have been counting myself happy､ that before thee am I about､ this day､ to be making my defence;
content_old: 2 Concerning all things of which I am accused by Jews, King Agrippa I have been counting myself happy､ that before thee am I about､ this day､ to be making my defence;

content: 3 especially as thou art well-versed in all the Jewish customs and questions. Wherefore､ I beseech thee patiently to hear me.
content_old: 3 especially as thou art well-versed in all the Jewish customs and questions. Wherefore､ I beseech thee patiently to hear me.

content: 4 My manner of life､ then､ from my youth, which from its commencement was formed among my nation､ even in Jerusalem know all Jews,
content_old: 4 My manner of life､ then､ from my youth, which from its commencement was formed among my nation､ even in Jerusalem know all Jews,

content: 5 inasmuch as they were aforetime observing me､ from the outset,—if they please to bear witness,—that according to the strictest sect of our own religion I lived a Pharisee.
content_old: 5 inasmuch as they were aforetime observing me､ from the outset,—if they please to bear witness,—that according to the strictest sect of our own religion I lived a Pharisee.

content: 6 And now for the hope of the promise unto our fathers being brought to pass by God am I standing to be judged,—
content_old: 6 And now for the hope of the promise unto our fathers being brought to pass by God am I standing to be judged,—

content: 7 unto which hope our twelve-tribed nation with intensity､ night and day､ rendering divine service is hoping to attain:—concerning which hope I am being accused by Jews, O King!
content_old: 7 unto which hope our twelve-tribed nation with intensity､ night and day､ rendering divine service is hoping to attain:—concerning which hope I am being accused by Jews, O King!

content: 8 What! incredible is it judged with you､ that God the dead doth raise?
content_old: 8 What! incredible is it judged with you､ that God the dead doth raise?

content: 9 I therefore､ imagined to myself, that against the name of Jesus the Nazarene it was needful many hostile things to bring about,—
content_old: 9 I therefore､ imagined to myself, that against the name of Jesus the Nazarene it was needful many hostile things to bring about,—

content: 10 which also I did in Jerusalem, yea and many of the saints I myself in prisons shut up,—the authority from the High-priests having received; and when they were to be put to death I brought against them my vote;
content_old: 10 which also I did in Jerusalem, yea and many of the saints I myself in prisons shut up,—the authority from the High-priests having received; and when they were to be put to death I brought against them my vote;

content: 11 and throughout all the synagogues ofttimes punishing them I would fain have compelled them to defame; and being excessively maddened against them I went on to pursue them as far as even the outlying cities.
content_old: 11 and throughout all the synagogues ofttimes punishing them I would fain have compelled them to defame; and being excessively maddened against them I went on to pursue them as far as even the outlying cities.

content: 12 Among which things being on a journey unto Damascus､ with the authority and commission of the High-priests
content_old: 12 Among which things being on a journey unto Damascus､ with the authority and commission of the High-priests

content: 13 at midday､ on the road I saw, O King, from heaven, above the splendour of the sun､ shining around me a light, and around them who with me were journeying;
content_old: 13 at midday､ on the road I saw, O King, from heaven, above the splendour of the sun､ shining around me a light, and around them who with me were journeying;

content: 14 and when we were all fallen to the ground I heard a voice､ saying unto me､ in the Hebrew language— Saul! Saul! why me art thou persecuting? It is hard for thee against goads to be kicking!
content_old: 14 and when we were all fallen to the ground I heard a voice､ saying unto me､ in the Hebrew language— Saul! Saul! why me art thou persecuting? It is hard for thee against goads to be kicking!

content: 15 And I said— Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said— I am Jesus, whom thou art persecuting!
content_old: 15 And I said— Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said— I am Jesus, whom thou art persecuting!

content: 16 But rise and stand upon thy feet; for to this end have I appeared unto thee,— To appoint thee an attendant and a witness, Both of the things as to which thou hast seen me､ And of those as to which I will appear unto thee:
content_old: 16 But rise and stand upon thy feet; for to this end have I appeared unto thee,— To appoint thee an attendant and a witness, Both of the things as to which thou hast seen me､ And of those as to which I will appear unto thee:

content: 17 Rescuing thee from among the people, and from among the nations､ Unto whom I am sending thee—
content_old: 17 Rescuing thee from among the people, and from among the nations､ Unto whom I am sending thee—

content: 18 To open their eyes; That they turn from darkness unto light､ And the authority of Satan unto God, That they may receive remission of sins､ And an inheritance among them who have been made holy by the faith respecting me.
content_old: 18 To open their eyes; That they turn from darkness unto light､ And the authority of Satan unto God, That they may receive remission of sins､ And an inheritance among them who have been made holy by the faith respecting me.

content: 19 Wherefore, O King Agrippa,— I became not disobedient unto the heavenly vision;
content_old: 19 Wherefore, O King Agrippa,— I became not disobedient unto the heavenly vision;

content: 20 But— Both to them in Damascus､ first, and in Jerusalem, Unto all the country of Judæa also, and unto the nations I carried tidings— That they should repent､ and turn unto God, And works worthy of their repentance should practise.
content_old: 20 But— Both to them in Damascus､ first, and in Jerusalem, Unto all the country of Judæa also, and unto the nations I carried tidings— That they should repent､ and turn unto God, And works worthy of their repentance should practise.

content: 21 Because of these things Jews seized me in the temple, and were attempting to slay me with their own hands.
content_old: 21 Because of these things Jews seized me in the temple, and were attempting to slay me with their own hands.

content: 22 So then having met with the help that is from God until this day do I stand､ witnessing to both small and great, nothing else saying､ than those things which both the prophets and Moses did say should certainly come to pass:—
content_old: 22 So then having met with the help that is from God until this day do I stand､ witnessing to both small and great, nothing else saying､ than those things which both the prophets and Moses did say should certainly come to pass:—

content: 23 If to suffer the Christ was destined, If the first of a resurrection of the dead he is about to carry tidings of light both unto the people､ and unto the nations.
content_old: 23 If to suffer the Christ was destined, If the first of a resurrection of the dead he is about to carry tidings of light both unto the people､ and unto the nations.

content: 24 Now as he was saying these things in his defence Festus with a loud voice saith— Thou art raving, Paul! Thy great learning is turning thee round unto raving madness.
content_old: 24 Now as he was saying these things in his defence Festus with a loud voice saith— Thou art raving, Paul! Thy great learning is turning thee round unto raving madness.

content: 25 But Paul— I am not raving (saith he), most noble Festus,—but the declarations of truth and soberness am I sounding forth:
content_old: 25 But Paul— I am not raving (saith he), most noble Festus,—but the declarations of truth and soberness am I sounding forth:

content: 26 For well-knoweth the king concerning these things, unto whom with boldness of utterance am I speaking; for that these things are not hidden from him I am well persuaded,—for not in a corner hath this thing been done.
content_old: 26 For well-knoweth the king concerning these things, unto whom with boldness of utterance am I speaking; for that these things are not hidden from him I am well persuaded,—for not in a corner hath this thing been done.

content: 27 Believest thou, King Agrippa, in the prophets? I know that thou believest!
content_old: 27 Believest thou, King Agrippa, in the prophets? I know that thou believest!

content: 28 And Agrippa said unto Paul— Almost art thou persuading me to become a Christian!
content_old: 28 And Agrippa said unto Paul— Almost art thou persuading me to become a Christian!

content: 29 And Paul answered— I could pray unto God that both almost and altogether, not only thou but all they who are hearing me this day might become such,—as even I am, excepting these bonds.
content_old: 29 And Paul answered— I could pray unto God that both almost and altogether, not only thou but all they who are hearing me this day might become such,—as even I am, excepting these bonds.

content: 30 And the king rose up､ and the governor, Bernicè also､ and they who had been sitting with them;
content_old: 30 And the king rose up､ and the governor, Bernicè also､ and they who had been sitting with them;

content: 31 and retiring they began conversing one with another, saying— Nothing worthy of death or of bonds doth this man practise.
content_old: 31 and retiring they began conversing one with another, saying— Nothing worthy of death or of bonds doth this man practise.

content: 1 Now when it was determined that we should sail for Italy they proceeded to deliver Paul､ and certain other prisoners､ unto a centurion by name Julius, of an Augustan band.
content_old: 1 Now when it was determined that we should sail for Italy they proceeded to deliver Paul､ and certain other prisoners､ unto a centurion by name Julius, of an Augustan band.

content: 2 And going on board a ship of Adramittium､ about to sail unto the places along the coast of Asia we put to sea, there being with us､ Aristarchus､ a Macedonian of Thessalonica;
content_old: 2 And going on board a ship of Adramittium､ about to sail unto the places along the coast of Asia we put to sea, there being with us､ Aristarchus､ a Macedonian of Thessalonica;

content: 3 and on the next day we put into Zidon,—aud Julius､ treating Paul kindly､ gave him leave to go unto his friends and refresh himself;
content_old: 3 and on the next day we put into Zidon,—aud Julius､ treating Paul kindly､ gave him leave to go unto his friends and refresh himself;

content: 4 and from thence putting out to sea we sailed under the lee of Cyprus､ because the winds were contrary;
content_old: 4 and from thence putting out to sea we sailed under the lee of Cyprus､ because the winds were contrary;

content: 5 and sailing across the sea which is off Cilicia and Pamphylia we came down to Myra､ a city of Lycia.
content_old: 5 and sailing across the sea which is off Cilicia and Pamphylia we came down to Myra､ a city of Lycia.

content: 6 And the centurion there finding a ship of Alexandria sailing for Italy put us therein.
content_old: 6 And the centurion there finding a ship of Alexandria sailing for Italy put us therein.

content: 7 And for a good many days sailing slowly､ and getting with difficulty over against Cnidus､ the wind not suffering us to get on we sailed under the lee of Crete､ over against Salmone;
content_old: 7 And for a good many days sailing slowly､ and getting with difficulty over against Cnidus､ the wind not suffering us to get on we sailed under the lee of Crete､ over against Salmone;

content: 8 and with difficulty coasting it we came to a certain place called Fair Havens, near to which was the city of Lasea.
content_old: 8 and with difficulty coasting it we came to a certain place called Fair Havens, near to which was the city of Lasea.

content: 9 And when a considerable time had passed, and sailing was already dangerous､ because even the Fast had already gone by Paul began to advise,
content_old: 9 And when a considerable time had passed, and sailing was already dangerous､ because even the Fast had already gone by Paul began to advise,

content: 10 saying to them— Sirs! I perceive that with damage and great loss､ not only of the cargo and of the ship､ but even of our persons shall the voyage certainly be attended.
content_old: 10 saying to them— Sirs! I perceive that with damage and great loss､ not only of the cargo and of the ship､ but even of our persons shall the voyage certainly be attended.

content: 11 But the centurion by the master､ and by the shipowner was more persuaded､ than by the things which by Paul were spoken.
content_old: 11 But the centurion by the master､ and by the shipowner was more persuaded､ than by the things which by Paul were spoken.

content: 12 And the harbour being incommodious to winter in the more part advised to put to sea from thence, if by any means they might be able to reach Phænix, to winter, which was a harbour of Crete､ looking north-east and south-east.
content_old: 12 And the harbour being incommodious to winter in the more part advised to put to sea from thence, if by any means they might be able to reach Phænix, to winter, which was a harbour of Crete､ looking north-east and south-east.

content: 13 And a south wind blowing softly supposing they had secured their purpose weighing anchor､ they began to sail close in shore along Crete.
content_old: 13 And a south wind blowing softly supposing they had secured their purpose weighing anchor､ they began to sail close in shore along Crete.

content: 14 But after no long time there beat down from it a tempestuous wind､ called Euraquilo,—
content_old: 14 But after no long time there beat down from it a tempestuous wind､ called Euraquilo,—

content: 15 and the ship being caught and we not being able to bring her head to the wind we let her go､ and were borne along.
content_old: 15 and the ship being caught and we not being able to bring her head to the wind we let her go､ and were borne along.

content: 16 And running under the lee of some small island called Cauda we were able､ with difficulty､ to make ourselves masters of the boat,—
content_old: 16 And running under the lee of some small island called Cauda we were able､ with difficulty､ to make ourselves masters of the boat,—

content: 17 which､ hoisting up､ they began to use helps, under-girding the ship; and fearing lest on the sand-bank of Africa they should run aground lowering the gear so were they borne along.
content_old: 17 which､ hoisting up､ they began to use helps, under-girding the ship; and fearing lest on the sand-bank of Africa they should run aground lowering the gear so were they borne along.

content: 18 But we being exceedingly tempest-tossed on the next day they began to throw cargo overboard;
content_old: 18 But we being exceedingly tempest-tossed on the next day they began to throw cargo overboard;

content: 19 and on the third day､ with their own hands the tackling of the ship they cast away.
content_old: 19 and on the third day､ with their own hands the tackling of the ship they cast away.

content: 20 And neither sun nor stars appearing for many days, and no small tempest lying upon us in the end all hope that we should be saved began to be taken from us.
content_old: 20 And neither sun nor stars appearing for many days, and no small tempest lying upon us in the end all hope that we should be saved began to be taken from us.

content: 21 But when they had been long without food then Paul､ standing in the midst of them, said— Ye ought､ indeed､ Sirs! yielding to me not to have sailed away from Crete, to get this damage and loss.…
content_old: 21 But when they had been long without food then Paul､ standing in the midst of them, said— Ye ought､ indeed､ Sirs! yielding to me not to have sailed away from Crete, to get this damage and loss.…

content: 22 And now I recommend you to be of good courage; for loss of life shall there be none at all from among you,—only of the ship.
content_old: 22 And now I recommend you to be of good courage; for loss of life shall there be none at all from among you,—only of the ship.

content: 23 For there stood by me this night belonging unto the God whose I am､ unto whom also I am doing divine service a messenger,
content_old: 23 For there stood by me this night belonging unto the God whose I am､ unto whom also I am doing divine service a messenger,

content: 24 saying— Be not afraid､ Paul! for before Cæsar must thou needs stand. And lo! God hath granted to thee as a favour､ all them who are sailing with thee.
content_old: 24 saying— Be not afraid､ Paul! for before Cæsar must thou needs stand. And lo! God hath granted to thee as a favour､ all them who are sailing with thee.

content: 25 Wherefore､ be of good courage, Sirs; for I believe in God—that so it shall be､ according as it hath been told me.
content_old: 25 Wherefore､ be of good courage, Sirs; for I believe in God—that so it shall be､ according as it hath been told me.

content: 26 Upon a certain island however､ must we needs be wrecked.
content_old: 26 Upon a certain island however､ must we needs be wrecked.

content: 27 And when the fourteenth night had come, and we were being driven to and fro in the Adriatic about midnight the sailors suspected that some country was nearing them;
content_old: 27 And when the fourteenth night had come, and we were being driven to and fro in the Adriatic about midnight the sailors suspected that some country was nearing them;

content: 28 and sounding they found twenty fathoms,—and going a little further､ and again sounding they found fifteen fathoms.
content_old: 28 and sounding they found twenty fathoms,—and going a little further､ and again sounding they found fifteen fathoms.

content: 29 And fearing lest haply on rocky places we should be wrecked out of stern cast they four anchors,—and began praying that day might dawn.
content_old: 29 And fearing lest haply on rocky places we should be wrecked out of stern cast they four anchors,—and began praying that day might dawn.

content: 30 But when the sailors were seeking to flee out of the ship, and had lowered the boat into the sea､ by pretext､ as though out of the prow they had been about to reach anchors
content_old: 30 But when the sailors were seeking to flee out of the ship, and had lowered the boat into the sea､ by pretext､ as though out of the prow they had been about to reach anchors

content: 31 Paul said unto the centurion､ and unto the soldiers— Except these abide in the ship ye yourselves cannot be saved!
content_old: 31 Paul said unto the centurion､ and unto the soldiers— Except these abide in the ship ye yourselves cannot be saved!

content: 32 Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.
content_old: 32 Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.

content: 33 And until day was about to dawn Paul continued to beseech one and all to take some food, saying— This day is the fourteenth day that in suspense､ fasting ye are completing,—having helped yourselves to nothing.
content_old: 33 And until day was about to dawn Paul continued to beseech one and all to take some food, saying— This day is the fourteenth day that in suspense､ fasting ye are completing,—having helped yourselves to nothing.

content: 34 Wherefore､ I beseech you to take some food,—for this lays a foundation for your safety; for of no one of you shall a hair of the head perish.
content_old: 34 Wherefore､ I beseech you to take some food,—for this lays a foundation for your safety; for of no one of you shall a hair of the head perish.

content: 35 And having said these things､ and taken a loaf he gave thanks unto God before all, and breaking it began to eat.
content_old: 35 And having said these things､ and taken a loaf he gave thanks unto God before all, and breaking it began to eat.

content: 36 And all becoming of good cheer they also helped themselves to food.
content_old: 36 And all becoming of good cheer they also helped themselves to food.

content: 37 Now we were､ in the ship､ in all､ about seventy-six souls.
content_old: 37 Now we were､ in the ship､ in all､ about seventy-six souls.

content: 38 And when they were satisfied with food they began lightening the ship, casting out the wheat into the sea.
content_old: 38 And when they were satisfied with food they began lightening the ship, casting out the wheat into the sea.

content: 39 And when day came they could not rocognise the land; but perceived a certain bay having a beach,—upon which they were minded､ if they could､ safely to bring the ship.
content_old: 39 And when day came they could not rocognise the land; but perceived a certain bay having a beach,—upon which they were minded､ if they could､ safely to bring the ship.

content: 40 And casting off the anchors they let them go into the sea,—at the same time loosening the lashings of the rudders, and hoisting up the foresail to the wind they made for the beach.
content_old: 40 And casting off the anchors they let them go into the sea,—at the same time loosening the lashings of the rudders, and hoisting up the foresail to the wind they made for the beach.

content: 41 But falling into a place where two seas met they ran the ship aground; and the foreship sticking fast remained immoveable, while the stern began to break up､ from the violence of the waves.
content_old: 41 But falling into a place where two seas met they ran the ship aground; and the foreship sticking fast remained immoveable, while the stern began to break up､ from the violence of the waves.

content: 42 Now the soldiers’ counsel turned out to be､ that they should kill the prisoners, lest any one should swim out and escape;
content_old: 42 Now the soldiers’ counsel turned out to be､ that they should kill the prisoners, lest any one should swim out and escape;

content: 43 but the centurion being minded to bring Paul safely through hindered them of their purpose, and ordered such as were able to swim､ to cast themselves overboard and get first to the land,—
content_old: 43 but the centurion being minded to bring Paul safely through hindered them of their purpose, and ordered such as were able to swim､ to cast themselves overboard and get first to the land,—

content: 1 And when we were safely through then we knew that the island was called Melita.
content_old: 1 And when we were safely through then we knew that the island was called Melita.

content: 2 And the natives began to shew us no common philanthropy; for kindling a fire they received us all, because of the rain that had set in､ and because of the cold.
content_old: 2 And the natives began to shew us no common philanthropy; for kindling a fire they received us all, because of the rain that had set in､ and because of the cold.

content: 3 But when Paul had gathered a certain lot of firewood into a bundle､ and laid it on the fire a viper by reason of the heat coming forth, fastened on his hand.
content_old: 3 But when Paul had gathered a certain lot of firewood into a bundle､ and laid it on the fire a viper by reason of the heat coming forth, fastened on his hand.

content: 4 And when the natives saw the brute､ hanging out from his hand they began to say one to another— Doubtless this man is a murderer, whom though brought safely through out of the sea Justice hath not suffered to live.
content_old: 4 And when the natives saw the brute､ hanging out from his hand they began to say one to another— Doubtless this man is a murderer, whom though brought safely through out of the sea Justice hath not suffered to live.

content: 5 He however､ shaking off the brute into the fire suffered no harm;
content_old: 5 He however､ shaking off the brute into the fire suffered no harm;

content: 6 whereas they were expecting､ that he was about to become inflamed､ or to fall down suddenly dead;—but when they had been long expecting､ and had observed nothing unusual happening unto him they changed their minds, and began to say he was a god.
content_old: 6 whereas they were expecting､ that he was about to become inflamed､ or to fall down suddenly dead;—but when they had been long expecting､ and had observed nothing unusual happening unto him they changed their minds, and began to say he was a god.

content: 7 Now in the neighbourhood of that place were lands､ belonging to the chief man of the island､ by name Publius,—who making us welcome for three days hospitably entertained us.
content_old: 7 Now in the neighbourhood of that place were lands､ belonging to the chief man of the island､ by name Publius,—who making us welcome for three days hospitably entertained us.

content: 8 And it so happened that the father of Publius with feverish heats and dysentery distressed was lying prostrate: unto whom Paul entering in and praying, laid his hands on him､ and healed him.
content_old: 8 And it so happened that the father of Publius with feverish heats and dysentery distressed was lying prostrate: unto whom Paul entering in and praying, laid his hands on him､ and healed him.

content: 9 And when this happened the rest also､ even they in the island who were sick were coming in and getting cured;
content_old: 9 And when this happened the rest also､ even they in the island who were sick were coming in and getting cured;

content: 10 who also with many honours honoured us, and when we were about to sail put on board such things as we might need.
content_old: 10 who also with many honours honoured us, and when we were about to sail put on board such things as we might need.

content: 11 And after three months we sailed in a ship which had wintered in the island, a ship of Alexandria､ whose ensign was—The Twin Brothers;
content_old: 11 And after three months we sailed in a ship which had wintered in the island, a ship of Alexandria､ whose ensign was—The Twin Brothers;

content: 12 and touching at Syracuse we tarried three days;
content_old: 12 and touching at Syracuse we tarried three days;

content: 13 whence going round we reached Rhegium; and after one day a south wind springing up on the second day we came to Puteoli;
content_old: 13 whence going round we reached Rhegium; and after one day a south wind springing up on the second day we came to Puteoli;

content: 14 where finding brethren we were entreated to tarry with them seven days;—and thus､ towards Rome we came.
content_old: 14 where finding brethren we were entreated to tarry with them seven days;—and thus､ towards Rome we came.

content: 15 And when from thence the brethren heard the tidings concerning us they came to meet us､ as far as The Market of Appius and the Three Taverns,—seeing whom Paul thanked God､ and took courage.
content_old: 15 And when from thence the brethren heard the tidings concerning us they came to meet us､ as far as The Market of Appius and the Three Taverns,—seeing whom Paul thanked God､ and took courage.

content: 16 And when we entered into Rome Paul was suffered to abide by himself､ with the soldier that guarded him.
content_old: 16 And when we entered into Rome Paul was suffered to abide by himself､ with the soldier that guarded him.

content: 17 And it came to pass､ after three days､ that he called together those who were the chief of the Jews; and when they came together he began to say unto them— I brethren, though I had done nothing against the people, or the customs of our fathers as a prisoner out of Jerusalem was delivered into the hands of the Romans;—
content_old: 17 And it came to pass､ after three days､ that he called together those who were the chief of the Jews; and when they came together he began to say unto them— I brethren, though I had done nothing against the people, or the customs of our fathers as a prisoner out of Jerusalem was delivered into the hands of the Romans;—

content: 18 who､ indeed､ when they had examined me were minded to set me at liberty､ because there was nothing worthy of death in me.
content_old: 18 who､ indeed､ when they had examined me were minded to set me at liberty､ because there was nothing worthy of death in me.

content: 19 But as the Jews spake against it I was constrained to appeal unto Cæsar,—not as though against my nation I had anything to bring by way of accusation.
content_old: 19 But as the Jews spake against it I was constrained to appeal unto Cæsar,—not as though against my nation I had anything to bring by way of accusation.

content: 20 For this cause therefore､ have I called for you､ to see and to speak with you; for on account of the hope of Israel this chain have I about me!
content_old: 20 For this cause therefore､ have I called for you､ to see and to speak with you; for on account of the hope of Israel this chain have I about me!

content: 21 And they said unto him— We have neither received letters concerning thee from the Jews, nor hath anyone of the brethren who hath arrived reported or spoken concerning thee､ anything ill.
content_old: 21 And they said unto him— We have neither received letters concerning thee from the Jews, nor hath anyone of the brethren who hath arrived reported or spoken concerning thee､ anything ill.

content: 22 But we deem it well､ that from thee we should hear what are thine opinions; for､ indeed､ concerning this sect it is known to us that everywhere is it spoken against.
content_old: 22 But we deem it well､ that from thee we should hear what are thine opinions; for､ indeed､ concerning this sect it is known to us that everywhere is it spoken against.

content: 23 And having arranged with him a day there came unto him､ to the lodging､ a larger number; unto whom he proceeded to expound, bearing full witness as to the kingdom of God､ and persuading them concerning Jesus, both from the law of Moses､ and from the prophets,—from morning till evening.
content_old: 23 And having arranged with him a day there came unto him､ to the lodging､ a larger number; unto whom he proceeded to expound, bearing full witness as to the kingdom of God､ and persuading them concerning Jesus, both from the law of Moses､ and from the prophets,—from morning till evening.

content: 24 And some indeed､ were persuaded by the things that were spoken, whereas others disbelieved;
content_old: 24 And some indeed､ were persuaded by the things that were spoken, whereas others disbelieved;

content: 25 and not being agreed among themselves they began to leave,—Paul having said one thing— Well did the Holy Spirit speak through Isaiah the prophet､ unto your fathers,
content_old: 25 and not being agreed among themselves they began to leave,—Paul having said one thing— Well did the Holy Spirit speak through Isaiah the prophet､ unto your fathers,

content: 26 saying— Go thy way unto this people, and say— Ye shall surely hear and yet will in nowise understand. And surely see and yet will in nowise perceive;
content_old: 26 saying— Go thy way unto this people, and say— Ye shall surely hear and yet will in nowise understand. And surely see and yet will in nowise perceive;

content: 27 For the heart of this people hath become dense, And with their ears､ heavily have they heard, And their eyes have they closed,— Lest once they should see with their eyes, And with their ears should hear, And with their hearts should understand､ and return,— When I would certainly heal them.
content_old: 27 For the heart of this people hath become dense, And with their ears､ heavily have they heard, And their eyes have they closed,— Lest once they should see with their eyes, And with their ears should hear, And with their hearts should understand､ and return,— When I would certainly heal them.

content: 28 Be it known unto you therefore, That unto the nations hath been sent forth this salvation of God: they will also hear.
content_old: 28 Be it known unto you therefore, That unto the nations hath been sent forth this salvation of God: they will also hear.

content: 30 And he abode two whole years in his own hired house, and made welcome all who wore coming in unto him,—
content_old: 30 And he abode two whole years in his own hired house, and made welcome all who wore coming in unto him,—
